if you have any sort of disability or require special working conditions, even to the extent that you need to take several days off a month because of your mental/physical health, Wells Fargo is the place for you. All you need is for a doctor to fill out a 6 page form stating what your condition is and what accommodations you require. With said documentation, Wells will bend over backwards to accommodate your mental/physical condition, as well as any situations that arise within your family . Whether it's only being able to work 6 hours a shift, needing to take emergency, extended family leave for a non life-threatening situation or being allotted several excused absences per month because of a chronic medical condition, Wells Fargo will adapt the schedule, the work environment, to the individual's needs instead of trying to force them into an untenable work situation which would result in an unhappy, underproductive employee who wouldn't last very long.

I'm not allowed to tell them what ALL their options are or I get into trouble, but if no one tells them something is possible, how will they know to ask? I feel like I often work with the customer AGAINST the company! I just want to be able to offer the customers the best options possible without getting into trouble.

I quit Wells in 2020. Internal Audit at Wells has had a MAJOR exodus of people leaving in 2019-2021 because of several reasons. You have to log all your time and meet productivity requirements. Meetings, trainings, don’t count. You have to somehow reach a 96% efficiency. It’s kind of like being in work prison. There is little to no chance of advancement. You have to invest years here before you are even considered. Favoritism abounds here. The audit process and systems are so complicated And convoluted, you’re going to be confused 99% of the time. Everything is always changing. Processes , templates, methodologies….everything. All the senior management are so worried about career advancement they undertake projects to improve things. That creates a HUGE mess. The company is so big and there are so many different lines of business it’s always chaotic and crazy. Too much to know and too little time focusing on actual audit work. Roles are never defined and you never know what you are responsible for. Too much work and not enough down time. You can’t reach out and contact people. You will get reprimanded for contacting the wrong people and asking a question. Everyone is kept fearful of senior management.

Opportunities for career advancements are dictated by an organizational growth chart which may require you to hold an intermediary position you don't want prior to being placed in the role you do want. 

Often times, those roles must first be held in low demand regions which could require you to relocate in order to advance. 

The only other workaround is to gain endorsement from higher ups which can often require a lot of sucking up. If you aren't prepared for that type of corporate culture than you are better off rising through the ranks by jumping into higher roles with competitors. 

(My experience is limited to that of the Retail Banking Sector, I cannot speak for others)

If you want to be a eunuch then Wells Fargo is the place for you! While they present an attractive image in their mission and value statements, the reality is quite different - the majority of people you interact with are dispirited, disillusioned, mentally exhausted, and unmotivated. They are just treading water until it is time to retire.

I have been in business for 27 years and worked previously at Wells over 20 years ago. The amazing thing is they have not grown as an organization in those past two decades. The same dominance-based structure is firmly in place - one that withholds information from the employees in order to allow the managers to feel they are in control. Perhaps they believe they are adding value? It is a pretty sad state of affairs when territorialism and protecting your image are the main goals of the so-called leadership (in actuality, 'rudderless ship' is the best analogy). Saul van Beurden is very compelling and seems open minded and helpful - but the reality is you will never work for anyone like him. Your managers will be barely literate and emotionally stunted individuals who never say 'Thank You' or acknowledge your work ('No, folks - a paycheck really is not enough!').

Purportedly they are implementing Agile but it is really Agile in name only; the teams are completely disempowered and unable to plan given the shifting requirements and paucity of information. Again, it feels like this is a control issue where the many levels of weak management don't want to face their approaching obsolescence.

Sad state of affairs - so many people wasting their lives working in meaningless job. It is a paycheck - and that is the best you can hope for at WF.

Everything else...poor community within organization. Zero engagement with team members. You won't get to know your coworkers beyond the work. Pay is relatively low for the amount of work/stress comes from the job. Company made well over 3x their annual revenue in 2021 and were sticklers when it came to yearly raises. Managed the COVID stuff very poorly and this stems from upper-upper management. You will be a number here. If you need team orientation, this gig is not for you.
Overworking existing staff due to inability to find proper replacements.
Relies on old technology but they are changing that

I initially took a contract offer from a middle manager within a growing part of the bank. I did great work and so she offered me a full time role. She promised that my current salary would match the full time. She waited 9 months from verbal offer to post my role, and then she left for a new team. The new manager (35 years with bank) offered me a 40% pay-cut. Said he spoke to the other manager and that's the best the bank could do. I wanted to stay a contractor but my time limit (I think it's 2 years) was coming due, and needed a job. So I took it with 30% pay cut. This bank left a terrible taste in my mouth.

Will try to be objective as possible, these are my 20+ year experience and observations from a direct role in infrastructure tech to interacting with software developers, business system consultants, tech/project managers and support desks. The order below is random, no priority. 

#01 Poor business ethics. Any job working in the financial sector, especially larger institutions, requires the ability to ignore certain realities.

#02 Double standards. This ties in with #01. Tech is required, as they should, to not have any unauthorized changes, not lose their laptop, follow processes accordingly, etc. Threats of termination for being out of compliance were directly relayed to me and my peers on the first day by our new vice president when WF acquired our smaller company. In my opinion, any infraction we do whether intended or not is not nearly as damaging as the questionable business practices executed by using the systems we are employed to keep running. 

#03 No clear paths for career advancement. Managers do not offer any career support; they are constantly worried/distracted about keeping their jobs; spend a lot of time in the trenches alongside their direct reports instead of being empowered to manage. 

#04 Unclear hiring practices. Sometimes the budget only allows hiring contractors, or hiring overseas, etc. Each time it can prevent internal candidates from advancement. This has affected me personally, where I ended up guiding a lower qualified new person in a higher role that I applied for.

#05 Little to no pay raise/promotions within internal role. As a lead, I went over 10 years without a promotion and when it did happen, it was a blanket promotion.

#06 Toxic working culture. Starts with management and goes on down. Rudeness on calls, hang ups, lack of accountability, no response to emails or chats, lack of professionalism with colleagues when requesting improvements. High performers will find themselves boxed out and being questioned for trying to go above and beyond. 

#07 Internal re-orgs take too much time. Tied to #05, if roles and responsibilites shift from one team to another, there isn't a clear path to make it happen. Some workers and managers choose to remain doing legacy functions, some do a hybrid of legacy/new functions. Anyone who wants to move forward will struggle with the pace of play.

#08 Lack of using existing data. Management can request data be manually inputted in a separate system when that data is already attainable and more accurate via existing databases. Workers then have to manage multiple systems.

#09 Overuse of email for work requests. Email is well past its prime. Internally there are a few widely known systems of record where requests can be submitted with built-in tracking, notifications, metrics, etc.

#10 Confusing bureaucratic processes. Typical of any big company, a lot of work is subject to interpretation. Catch someone on a nice day, they'll help you avoid time-consuming order and approval forms. Going normal routes to request work is quite the journey and takes time away from interesting or more pressing tech work.

#11 Reactionary unstructured approach to work. If an event happens, say a rare power outage at a critical site, it can derail all other important projects and force everyone to focus on disaster recovery in the moment. It isn't a problem to shift focus to respond to current conditions, it is a problem to shift focus without any strategy.

#12 Unclear roles and responsibilities. It is good to have minimal boundaries in day to day work, as long as it is understood what your primary role is and what is expected of you. 

#13 Aging workforce is terribly slow to accept change, regardless of complexity.

#14 Skills advancement/training is poor. There is an expansive library of internal courses with a cumbersome interface to use; not all courses are available at certain times, not all are free.

#15 Agile methodologies lack vision and support. For those who aren't software developers, Agile is a major change to how you approach work each day. Some think Agile means "just get it done fast, clean it up later", instead of appreciating it as a formal method for efficiency. 

#16 The worst is always behind, better days ahead right? If I was interviewing today, this is what I would ask and would want to know details.

No career advancement as promised for PB1. No increase in pay for PB1 to do both roles 2 jobs)(banker and teller). Not enough training time given to pb1s to take on teller role. Staffing issues especially when PB1 is worked more as a teller than a banker. Relationship bankers get paid more to do less and actually do less to sit in their offices and wait on referrals from pb1s and tellers. No consideration of pb1 in regards to whether they want to do the job of a teller just mandatory change with no pay increase to do 2 jobs. Overworked and underpaid. Relationship bankers treat pb1 as secretaries to set them up for referrals while having no incentives or pay for pb1s to refer and branch management is behind the process. Branch management doesn't follow up on creating an teamwork environment as far as stopping other people from taking places of authority that HAVE NOT been placed in authority. (Relationship banker). Branch management just let's things slide instead of confronting issues with relationship banker. Company tries to control people's choices. No incentives, appreciation or recognition for loyal employees. Company tends to choose customers over employees. Anyone in the role below a relationship banker has no appealing attraction, incentive, or bonus to want to stay (in one person's opinion.)

I would also question some of the strategic decisions by management. Just a small example. Wells sold its 401k administration business to Prudential. Then, they selected a different vendor (Empower) to administer their 401k plan going forward. Empower does not have any electronic connectivity to Wells Fargo Advisors (apparently Wells is one of the few brokers that does not have electronic connectivity to Empower). Wells sells this business to a vendor that they themselves are not willing to use going forward, and then they pick an alternative that can't easily roll 401k accounts over their internal brokerage operation. Who makes these decisions?

Management is horrible, you can express your concerns, problems, offer solutions and be enthusiastic about improvement and growing within the company. It really means nothing. Wells Fargo has no problem with demanding certain expectations of their employees when it comes to sales, production goals etc. However, they do not operate by the same standards. The workplace culture is more focused on micro management. (even though it appears no one really knows how to do their job) Lastly, they will implement changes randomly and add on more responsibility with little to no training or compensation. This place will truly have you working harder, making less, and confused about whether or not you actually know how to do your job.

My colleagues at Wells Fargo were very professional and made my time there the highlight of my banking experience. Prior to the scandal the bank’s leadership outside of consumer banking had much more authority and the banks ability to be competitive was fun and winning meaningful relationships and positively impacting customers was commonplace. After the scandal became the central focus it was a completely different work place for all areas of the bank which 95% of the bank had nothing to do with the account scandal. The former leader of the consumer side of the business and her unquestioned support from the CEO of the bank at that time was the downfall for this organization.
They had a lot of upward mobility for the employees that could make the sales goals long enough to stick around

The bank lost its direction after the account scandal broke. No one employee including the CEO (he was in denial) really understood the changes that would be forthcoming once the effects of this fully took effect. The bank no longer was in control of its narrative nor was it capable of communicating to its employees what was going on with its regulatory enforcements that never stopped coming. Being an employee at Wells Fargo is not something I would recommend to anyone in the next few years unless you are looking for mission impossible and your work will never culminate into a feeling of satisfaction. My role was the tip of the spear in helping the bank bring in new customer relationships. As part of the banks effort to appease a multitude of its regulatory issues, the bank set up a number of safety towers or silos (operating separately of one another). This sounds like it was a good idea, but because the leaders of these various silos operated independently of each other and did not communicate it was a complete nightmare to get anything done productive and help create positive outcome. The time it took to board a new relationship is typically many months and not weeks as most banks board new clients. The culture of the bank has become one of fear and uncertainty. By in large there are fewer senior experienced bankers working as they are leaving for other opportunities. By in large, turnover is not occurring in higher salaried enployees despite the dysfunction because they won’t have someone pay them what they make at WF. The higher paid employees typically comprised of senior leadership are under tremendous pressure as their top performers are running over them getting out the door.

It's highly dependent on who you work for. I worked in several departments during my tenure and there were massive "re-orgs" every few months. It's a big overblown company that can't figure itself out. They aren't work from home friendly, a big reason everyone jumps ship recently (when they aren't laying people off). This policy on this differs manager to manager and isn't global. Work life balance can be great with one manager and horrible with another. I was told verbatim from the top-down that promotions are only going to be given to those who "put in extra work on nights and weekends.". Maybe you'll get lucky and have a manager that doesn't believe in that, maybe you'll end up in a bad group. HR is a big mess - I've dealt with really nice people who want to help you and others who were some of the most rude and unprofessional people I've had the displeasure of speaking with. I'd highly recommend that you do a LOT of Q&A during your interview with the hiring manager to make sure it's where you want to be.

- not many opportunities for advancement

Terrible upper management, will not be promoted unless you are in the "in" crowd.

Slow, antiquated internal systems. Customer interface systems given priority. Reputation slowly recovering from deposit/auto insurance/home mortgage scandals. Focusing on upscale Commercial clients at the expense of smaller Business Banking clients (who become wholesale clients).

The work itself was unfulfilling, the work environment was your typical stuffy cubicle with management hovering over you, the yearly pay increases were a joke (less than 1%), work from home (pre pandemic) was NOT an option even if there was a blizzard, and management would jerk you around promising promotions and raises then not delivering.

There used to be so many great benefits/perks of working at WF. Those benefits made up for working very long hours, having to work unexpectedly during PTO, skipping a lunch break to eat on mute during back-to-back meetings, etc. When you have to work 8am-7pm regularly as a salaried employee, being able to do so at home makes it sting a lot less. Now that they are taking away the ability to work from home most days, I can't imagine how I will get all of the work done and commute home in time to start dinner, exercise, take care of kids, etc. just to wake up, sit in traffic, and do it all over again. I'm going to have to start saying no to the new assignments that come to me at 5pm and are due at 8am. Taking away the ability for high performing/producing employees to spend their long workdays at home is really disappointing. Especially when we've been doing it for over a decade, and other companies are offering it even more now. Other benefits have also been taken away recently - no raises last year for certain level of employees, no 401K match until Dec 31, cell phones taken away, laptops are next. I want to remain a loyal employee but it is getting more difficult every year.

There is a lot of change going on at Wells Fargo and it isn't headed in the right direction. It used to be an organization that seemed to respect tenure and truly care for its employees but as far as I can tell, those days are over. If you want to work for a bank that is trying to become like JPM but pays less, then it might be a good choice.

Training was simultaneously very thorough and very sink-or-swim at the same time. I felt mostly prepared going into the role but once I was on the floor taking calls I realized quickly how much had been left out. There were a great deal of important job functions that weren't covered in training that I and the others who trained with me had to ask coworkers about. 

Time on the phones and time in general was very micromanaged down to the minute. If you spent too long on a call or too long in wrap it was only a matter of time until someone was on the case about it no matter how reasonable it was or how detailed the notes were. This isn't necessarily true of the company as a whole but in my role with my boss I felt as though my failures were recognized disproportionately to my successes.

At the time that I was working with Wells Fargo the company was in the news a lot for any number of scandals. We were always being emailed about them and briefed on how to respond if certain things came up in conversation, or how to redirect them to a team geared to speak with the media and things like that. It was frustrating having to keep on top of it all, especially when most of it had nothing to do with my role whatsoever.

Lastly, collections for home mortgage was just a distressing job. That isn't Wells Fargo's fault but it's true of the role even so. It was difficult to hear people talk about the massive obstacles in their life getting in the way of them paying their home loan and hearing their distress in being told they're at risk of losing their home if they don't pay, and there's only so much we as employees can do about that. Being unable to help people beyond a certain extent when their only wrongdoing is not having money to live on felt terrible and acknowledging that on the floor felt like an admission of weakness. I felt like "the bad guy" a lot. It wasn't the worst job but I'm glad I don't work there anymore.

Corporate takes WAY to long to hire anyone. There is no help, customers are angry about the long wait times and they take it out on the staff who are trying their absolute best. 

You only get a 30 minute break, even if you work 8 hours. Normally you get two 15 minute breaks and a 30, but since there is no one to cover - you don't get to take a break from nasty, rude, and condescending customers.

You are expected to keep smiling and say things perfectly and with the perfect tone, or you will get disciplined. Staff is absolutely pushed to their breaking point with no understanding from managers or breaks to cool off from tough interactions.

If you get it wrong - don't be surprised that you are blamed for the entire interaction (even if the customer started off in a foul mood) and then shamed for not being perfect 100% of the time. I understand being good to the customer, but with no breaks, long lines out the door, rude and nasty customers, and managers who refuse to see their staff at their boiling point - yeah you are not going to have a perfect customer interaction every single time.

I had left my position within 2 months of joining. They care about burn down charts and statistics, and not the quality of the work being done. Micromanagement rules there. Managers are abusive and this is non productive for getting anything done. They offer destructive criticism.  The managers are people that have been at wells since the beginning of time so their is no touching them, but at the end of the day, Wells will suffer for not cleaning up their rotting upper management. I felt I was working more towards preserving my narcissist manager's ego rather than working for Wells Fargo itself. Instead of looking into the system and learning the code, I felt I was studying for my one on one meetings with the tyrant. Maybe it was my team, but I could see they really need to clean up the act. Managers need not use constant intimidation tactics. Not only do they do that, managers also keep a few brown nosing suck ups to keep tabs on others for them. People are so insecure about their jobs that they do not help anyone out, and collaboration is dead in the water.

Politics play a big role on promotions.

The one constant is change. Some District Managers are micromanagers and never let up. Managers are no longer allowed to come in early or stay late to have uninterrupted time. High expectations with a reduced staff.
It is a big bank after all, so it’s common to feel like just a number or replaceable in the grand scheme of things.

Inconsistencies between the branch and phone bank leads to customer dissatisfaction. Current downsizing resulted stressful environment. Inconsistent branch operations leads to customer dissatisfaction. Little ability to submit employee feedback to the upper management.

If you plan on moving up there are many empty promises even if you put in the work. We were given a chance to work remote temporarily for 4 months and they had announced it would be for Business PPP loans. I agreed to transfer roles from Personal Banker so I would have more exposure in that thinking it would be a temporary position that would last a few months. We go through training and it turns out they transferred us to a regular call center for customer service having nothing to do with PPP loans. It was a way for Wells Fargo to remove personal bankers and make room for more licensed bankers. Prior to my decision to work remote I was waiting to start my licensed banker training and the district manager had announced they removed sponsoring the license. Now I am stuck working in the call center within Wells Fargo and have all this PTO time that is impossible to schedule within a call center and there are no holiday hours because the call center is available 24/7. I wasn’t the only Personal Banker that this happened to and several others were tricked into thinking it would be a temporary position to enhance our skills in Business. It was described as such by our District manager- and the licensed bankers who applied were the only people who were able to return from the “temporary position” they were all called back in to their branches. When bankers started speaking up and we all communicated in training that this wasn’t what we signed up for they “escalated” it to HR and we’ve heard nothing since. The unfortunate part of this all is that call center locations are located in more rural areas and there is no call center in the state I am in. So what’s going to happen to us that are not physically located near these call centers when everything opens up? Remote work is not going to be forever especially as a call center representative. I believe by then they will weed us out instead of furloughing us or firing us because the company wasn’t doing well during COVID this is the tactic they used to displace us slowly since they didn’t want any bad media for what they are doing to us. I wish they had just let us go before because we would have received unemployment benefits at the time since we didn’t receive any bonus for working during covid as essential workers. They will end up giving us an ultimatum as things begin to reopen- either quit or move to the state where the call center location is open to resume work. We’ll see how this scheme of theirs goes!

In the WF tech world its normal to see managers overseeing an engineering group who have no engineering experience. Mid level/upper level management in tech fields are normally MBA's with a finance background who know little about the systems they support. Most of the systems and processes make no sense. Every 2-3 years everything changes depending on who's in charge and before the dust settles it changes again... usually to the way it was prior. You can bet that management will always go for the cheaper option vs the better option. Scandal after scandal after government mandate was caused by poor sr. management. Training is a slapdash, and managers are revolving doors often not fully knowing how to do what their team does. Being competent earns you harder work, higher volumes, and pressure to be a resource for (train) your coworkers.
As a grunt, you need to let your manager know how they can help you. Too bad managers are stuck in daily meetings with upper management. So, they're hard pressed for time other than when they do get around to meet with you for your monthly meeting, and any other meetings where they reward your competency by asking you to help unclog a backlog, or ask you to give ideas on how you can prevent mistakes from occurring again.
Everyone's overloaded, but the pressure on the grunts where jobs actually land is immense. Then jobs are reassigned to competent saps who show up to work every day. To top it off, the branches pushing the credits are belligerent and any feigned positive communication they give belies the overall abusive culture.

- Salary! I make six figures and get a bonus. It’s incredible. 
- Supportive bosses
- Wonderful benefits, especially medical and vacation. Max out of pocket deductible for 2021 is $3500 for me. I think they start you with three weeks of vacation, then give you four when you hit three years. You also get two personal days, two days to volunteer, and a bunch of federal holidays.
- Wonderful advancement opportunities. You can also see the pay scale if it’s an internal job posting.
- Awesome work/life balance. I can start my day at 9 and shut off my computer around 6. Could depend on my job, but there has rarely been an instance where I had to work super late.

I have to also give them kudos for putting a lot of emphasis on diversity and inclusion lately.

I spent ten months with Wells Fargo. I spent six months doing work that was completely unrelated to my auditing job with the RCC team. I understood that this was due to COVID-19 and dealt with it. When I finally made it to my audit team I received very little guidance on what my job was, how to do it, and when tasks were due. Things were continuing to get worse as time went on and I felt that these factors were making doing the audit with a reasonable standard of competency impossible. I was told that other audit associates had different experiences on their teams but this was also told to me by the recruiter during what was effectively an exit interview. Training is very inconsistent in quality and depends largely on which audit team you are assigned.

The work itself is fairly easy but it requires accessing multiple systems of record and these are not intuitive systems that you'll be able to find by guesswork. You'll need training on how to do all of this as well and that was largely the problem I ran into with my team. I felt like my degree in accounting and previous work experience in accounting were largely useless here. Ultimately I left because I felt that my lack of knowledge was negatively affecting my performance on the job and also my teams performance as they relied on my to do audit work and other work.

The English language fails to truly describe how awful of a company this truly is. "Do as we say; don't do as we do" should be the moto.
Example Set 1: Having your work badge sent to the wrong city, having inoperable devices dropped on your desk, and not having the tech staff show up to be sure your systems are working until after you have done their job for them in the first week.
Example set 2: Having systems so slow they compete with dialup speeds, and you are doing jobs that require processing of tens of thousands of records. This is only one example of how the company will routinely set you up without what you need. It would be about the equivalent of a mechanic being asked to fix a car with their bare hands and hardly any tools.
Example Set 3: Constant hypocracy. Transparency, candidness, honesty are talked about frequently as company values. On the flip side, there is a compliance department that requires you to disclose all of your investment activity without even telling you what they are doing with it, or informing you about who has access. If you bother to express your dissatisfaction in a candid manner, you are reprimanded because nobody is to dare challenge that department. 
I could go on and on. You will find constantly you are told to follow one process, and then before even giving you enough time to switch, the company will change processes not giving you the chance to adjust, or even get the right footing. There are processes in place that might even be illegal (like the surveillance of your investments). You will not find more sloppy communication than what you will see here. If you are a low-level hire, and can't find a job somewhere else, you might love it here. It is definitely a place for people with incredibly low standards.

It's quite unfortunate but I had to fight to get my breaks, didn't get them until I contacted the district manager. I was also hired as a 20 hour teller but they were working me 40+ hours per week with only Sunday off. It was exhausting especially because I didn't get my breaks. There was a lot of work place drama and no one would hold the people spreading drama accountable. I had one team member bully me and be extremely rude to me in front of customers. She would only get talked to but nothing would change. Some team members would talk ill about other members, they wouldn't celebrate someone birthday because he didn't participate in anyone's birthday (bring some kind of food or buy something for someone) They also completely forgot about mine until I said something and the branch manager just threw me a happy birthday card while with a customer. It makes you feel horrible when everyone gets a birthday party with balloons, streamers, flowers and big signs. I didn't get any of that. It was a very toxic environment to work in and I'm glad I'm out of it. However the company was great to work for but the branch I worked at was horrendous and toxic.

pros:
An accomplished and business savvy professional with robust experience acquired over the years in delivering optimal results & business value in high-growth environments and establishing key relationships with business segments globally. An insightful information Technology Director with more than 15 years of experience specializing in strategic business leadership, technology expertise, and generating revenue growth. Track record of success increasing profits while handling complex matters with multiple initiatives in rapidly evolving technology sectors. Thrive in navigating ever-changing business needs and emerging technologies, improving operational processes, systems, and security, and continuously drives cost savings and fiscal efficiency. Devise a new strategy based on increased utilization, development of lower-cost technologies, updated certification methodologies, accelerated commercialization schedule, and improved allocations. Known for rapidly identifying issues by using root causes analysis and responding with plans and execution that resolve problems and often improve on previous operations. The company has gone through huge changes. The sales quota fiasco was a nightmare to live through, and the culture has remained. It's all about numbers. Micromanagement is present everywhere you look. Constant 1-on-1 meetings with your manager, constant evaluations. A very toxic work environment. 

Ultimately a lot of your experience at WF will depend on your Branch Manager. Branch Managers are promoted based on meeting sales goals, not their skill at managing teams. This leads to a whole team of bullying managers. People at my branch dreaded coming to work each day and celebrated when the Branch Manager was gone.

A lot has been done to repair the company's image. But employee morale is at an all-time-low with layoffs, quotas (yes, they still exist), and increasing micromagement. Employees are unhappy, customers are still being pressured, and the company is not doing well financially. It is, without a doubt, a sinking ship.

You don’t get enough training and can’t use that as a valid excuse for when you make any mistake
You will be audited twice every month when you get out of training and things begin to count against you. Once you’re out of training, you can’t get below 97% accuracy a month (which equates to literally no mistakes because of the way audits are weighted) and if you fail your audits 5 out of a 6 month rolling period, you’re done. There’s no question or review as to how little your mistakes were or how nit picky the quality audit team was, you’re just fired. 
They keep raising the quality audit bar to make it almost impossible to pass every every month. Seems that they would rather fire people for ‘quality’ instead of just laying off from a VERY busy department
A lot of management has never worked your position but will try to ‘relate’ with you
Get ready to work a lot of mandatory overtime. The claim flow is so busy but they won’t hire enough

The sad part is when I started with another bank which I will leave unnamed they were amazing. Then WF bought us out and that was when I discovered what being in hell was like. They put on the mask like they were changing the company for the good but in reality employees were overworked and underpaid. The turnover was higher then any other company I have worked at. This was due to a combination of things, one was that new hires were not given enough training to feel confident to do the job, others could not keep up with the fast pace, some realized that the sales part of the job was the entire job and was lacking the customer service we were supposed to be giving. Then you have others being termed for mistakes, a lot were probably due to lack of training and or coaching so instead of coaching the employees they normally just termed them. The growth oppt. was very little unless you wanted to go from a teller to a sales position and manager only if another leaves. Don't even consider lead teller because the salary was barely higher then the teller. I recall countless times were entire stores were being termed due to gaming. I also recall countless times were others were sabotaging each other. The leaders acted more like ditators then partners. They would work against you instead of with you and thought that talking to everyone like they were a child would gain respect. The sales goals expected from the employees in every position were so unrealistic and over the top that I can see why so many were not interested in staying. Most would go work at other banks altogether where they could focus on the customer rather than focus on what else they can sell to them. After so many years of seeing this all unfold I felt that being in an environment where everyone around me was so toxic was not healthy. The above things that I shared were not things happening to me, these were observations and when I see things being done over and over and nothing ever changes (even when we have spoke up about it) then sometimes its better to move on. I decided to pursue other ventures. Leaving that company was the biggest weight off of my shoulders ever. I hope that things have gotten better since then.

Wells Fargo is flailing trying to stay afloat. It is now trying everything it can to get rid of as many US employees in technology as possible and replace them with offshore employees at a fraction of the cost. The pandemic has only made this trend worse.

The experiment started about 7 years ago. Two separate management chains, which only diverge about a level or two below the CEO. Offshore is completely unaccountable to anyone in the US, and their performance is abysmal. US employees take the blame for their mistakes and often have to work extra to fix them.

Wells has always had a bad time managing underperforming employees. Employees who routinely do the jobs of 3 or more people are never promoted or given raises, while those who do nothing climb the ladder quickly. With offshore, that is magnified 10 times. Most offshore managers only care to increase their headcounts, with no regard for actual delivery of work. The project I work on has steadily collapsed under their weight, as every US employee who leaves is replaced by 3 offshore employees who do literally nothing, if you are lucky. I have "coworkers" who haven't made a single check-in in over 3 years. They are being promoted.

What we are now seeing is most of the valuable US employees being given negative performance reviews, including those who have literally done the work of 7 people for more than 5 years. Management does not care. They have targets to meet, and they will meet them.

It is abundantly clear the Wells Fargo is moving to a 100% offshore technology model at the expense of its US employees. We get no bonuses. We get no new hires. They get tons of bonuses for no work, and always seem to have new job reqs opening.

It. Is. Hell. Here. I'm literally just waiting until they lay me off so I can get a severance package. I hate every second of this place and cannot wait to leave.

The 10+ years at Wells Fargo have been both kind and unkind. Below are the things I enjoyed most.
The work is (mostly) meaningful, and sometimes treated as professionals by management. The people are technically savvy (some even smarter than myself, LOL) and really great to work with. I got along really well with most others, as long as we all focused on the premise that we are working for the same employer trying to accomplish roughly the same goal: building a better Wells Fargo one day at a time and one person at a time.
The pay is really good. Healthcare and related benefits are decent, but could be better. Paid holidays and PTO are satisfactory. Increasing PTO is a good way to keep employees. 401k matching to 6 percent is a gift, as was the ability to obtain an internal loan from the 401k balance was a lifesaver. 
The corporate cell phone and other technical equipment made the work more bearable. Although some years were considered "tight" and expenses were minimized or eliminated, having a corporate cell phone to separate personal and business calls makes all the difference. Also, having an option for a MacBook was much better than not allowing them at all (Thank you for merging with Wachovia Bank), and also allowed me to perform calculations and programming much better than the Windows laptops.
I enjoyed the 16 hours paid volunteer time, as well as matched donations to non-profits. Wells Fargo did a great job encouraging volunteerism and giving back to communities.

As someone with "disabilities", there were little accommodations that actually helped me feel like I was being heard, understood, and accepted by my immediate management. Instead, I was treated like a child until I raised my performance level, and was micro-managed for over a year, until laid off in December, 2020.
New upper management have raised several concerns and started workstreams/workgroups that will hopefully add some light at the end of the tunnel, however, it is a little too late for abuses that have already occurred and mindsets already set in stone. Despite the major abuses already discovered (2015 customer account abuses and subsequent regulation changes, 2009 Network Engineer burnout lawsuit, others), similar abuses still continue today due to the legacy Wells Fargo mindset to force employees to work until they burnout and leave, or are displaced at or above age 50. There are a few good managers, and most of the employees are awesome to work with, however, many have left or been pushed out due to lack of following with the marching orders.
There are no real career paths laid out, unless you want to become a political manager and move up the management chain of command. I and many others have suffered under this regime, and I have had little to no ability to move into the career path I really wanted. There was no time because I gave all of my energy and time to my day job, I was not given the opportunity to learn skills to move into the career I wanted to (no solid training courses or programs), and again, no tangible support from managers to help employees to grow.
Some of the new strategies from executive management are good, but several do not make sense for a majority of the technical staff, such as the migration to BYOD. Such strategies make sense for securing Wells Fargo assets, however, leave the employees out to fend for themselves. What about employees who cannot afford the necessary technology to perform their job? What about employees with little knowledge or ability to secure their home network?
Corporate technology that was paid for by Wells Fargo is increasingly watched and bogged down with security software to restrict and log every possible function, even if it is required by the job function or duties. Even my assigned MacBook Pro would turn the fan up and max out on resources on its own, or even crash the OS with no answers for many months.

Wells Fargo Home Mortgage (WFHM) is a great place to work for individuals with a background in mortgage and real-estate (such as appraisal, lending & underwriting, debt-collection, customer service, and business analysis), but it is heavily dominated by the paraprofessional class (i.e., those who majored in degrees that have nothing to do with banking or finance). In that sense it provides an excellent opportunity for those who have not had much luck finding work in their respective majors.

The Good: 

Wells Fargo provides great benefits for permanent employees and career-advancement for those who are dedicated and driven. WFHM in particular provides a relaxed environment to its employees and offers a great deal of independence (not a whole lot of micromanagement) in addition to sparing you from a lot of unnecessary hype, such as morale-boosting exercises and/or meetings.

In addition, virtually any mortgage experience on your resume carries some value in credentialing you for other mortgage careers.

This means that you could theoretically work an enjoyable position for years only to find yourself jobless the next. Wells Fargo also has a 6-month obligatory waiting period in between contracts so you aren't likely to return to your old position after having been let go.

The culture is such that, historically, no one wanted to make a decision, so they just added staff hoping THEY would make the decisions. This has resulted in a HUGE amount of unnecessary employees that just make work to justify their existence. Hopefully, the new CEO and his cadre will see through the "DEEP STATE" smoke and mirrors and cut out a lot of the fat around the waistline.

I went through the licensing program through associate staffing. You get 1 shot at passing the SIE industry essentials, Series 7 & 66. Luckily for me I was able to pass them, if you fail any of these tests you will be let go from your contract. Once passing all the tests you will be interviewed for the role. The job is pretty much guaranteed at this point since they spent the money getting you licensed for the role. As most of you know already, these particular licenses enable you to provide financial advice regarding investments such as Mutual Funds. However, in this specific role you’re unable to give any advice. There are 3 products you get to discuss with customers which would be a Wells Trade Account, Intuitive investor, or offering a phone based or full service FA. The customer has to decide which of these options is best for them. As the licensed associate you’re not able to tell them what would be best, oftentimes this creates an awkward experience between you and the customer because they’re looking at you to be the expert and know what would be best suited for them. The role is basic and becomes mundane fast. 

Expect to be taking back to back calls for your entire shift. 
Expect to repeat disclosures on every call. 
Expect your calls to be reviewed constantly and brought to your attention if you failed to state verbatim one of the 5+ disclosures. 
Expect to work Saturdays if you’re new. 
Expect to be in the role for a very long time, I was in the role for 2 years. I was constantly looking to get into an analytical role. Despite being in the role 2 years I was unable to interview for any other position I applied for internally. As for my colleagues they experienced the same problems regarding internal promotions. 
Expect your manager to miss all your 1 on 1 meetings. 
Expect to be a number and a droid. 
Expect upset customers, as most customers resent WFA for the scandals and disorganized client services group. 
Expect to regret the job you have chosen. 

On the final note I wanted to share the moment I was working Saturday in March 2020, when the COVID pandemic was on the rise and a stay at home order was issued by the NC governor. During work on Saturday a gentlemen in a hazmat suit showed up at my desk, informing me they would be spraying because someone in a nearby cubicle had been quarantined for being in close contact with someone who had COVID. My colleague and I, who were the only 2 scheduled at the Charlotte site on that particular Saturday were flabbergasted to say the least. My lazy employer failed to mention to us they were spraying the building that day for COVID. My manager asked me for a picture of the gentleman in the hazmat suit, I took the photo on my cellphone sent it to my boss. He told us to leave immediately and that we would be compensated for a full day of work. Later my boss calls my personal cell on my time to tell me the photos I have taken were illegally obtained, since I took the photos on private property. He asked me to delete the photos and call any of my family members I sent them to, so they could also delete them from their phones. Unbelievable, right? 

Anyway don’t work for this company, anyone who currently works there in the ICC contact centers will be in my prayers. Perhaps, all departments aren’t bad, I just speak for the ICC contact centers AKA call center.

I’ve worked here in the department for less than 10 months. My department has been transitioned to 2 other departments since starting. This means I’ve had 3 roles since I started, which is incredibly unorthodox I believe, but I do understand Covid made somethings different. It wouldn’t be a big deal except every time I’ve been “trained” for my roles with WF, there has been almost ZERO training.  Even my manager doesn’t get trained or seem to know things. The job itself is fine, but talk about stress when you’re asked to do a job after literally 1-2 hrs of training and thrown new customers every day. I was in a call with my bosses, bosses, boss and when a question was presented with concerns about the constant transitions, they were told “HLP’s are here to execute leaderships goals, that’s the end of it.” After hearing that response, I’ve never, ever felt so much like a number and my opinion as employee is not cared for. I definitely have learned that if you work at Wells Fargo you do not get to express ANY concerns and if you do management makes you feel like you’re in the wrong for bringing it up. 

When it comes to the work itself, not anyone else seems to care about helping the customers than The HLP and HMC, who are bound to the underwriters schedule to look at anything. Customers are always disappointed in WF lack of concern on purchases/refinances. 

Also, there isn’t really any additional benefit given to employees who get Covid other than STD. Many other companies allowed you to take time off or made schedule adjustments for those with children related to Covid issues, but  not WF.
Career growth within is very challenging. Needs Improvement

If you are working in operations, don't count on job security or even basic human rights. You can't even go to the bathroom without scrutiny. If you are working elsewhere it might not be so bad, but Wells Fargo is so hard to do business with. They are such a high friction company, and what I mean by that is that it takes 4 forms and a blood sample to link a brokerage account and a bank account. It takes a minimum of 14 business days to have a simple transfer-on-death account reviewed, only for it to be rejected 90% of the time for the littlest thing. Usually something along the lines of putting a middle name when they only needed a middle initial. Everything is an extreme process, that gets handled by teams that would rather reject it than help you complete it.

WF has great benefits. They're very helpful when setting up your benefits when you're a new hire. They value diversity--so if you're bilingual, your chances of getting hired increases. Their 2-weeks training program is exceptional. When I was first hired and told there was a mandatory 2-week full time training, I thought it was too much, but it really prepared me in the best way before they put me in a drawer by myself. Because WF was just under heat because of the scandal when I was hired, in my year and a half there I got two raises without asking for it because they increased the base-pay for everyone. Now, it's much higher than when I worked there.

Decent PTO and holidays. Management generally let's you work flex time - I am not a morning person and generally didn't get to work before 9am. My manager never gave me a hard time about it as long as I got 40 hours in. Bonus was about 10% of my base as long as quality was good. Also I felt that quality control was generally pretty fair in their reviews, although others disagree with me on that. Overall I was appreciative to have this job.

Not able to get your DE unless you worked in a particular physical office in 2 states only; lots of regulation impact on employees - such as, not allowed to use excel (seriously, and if you were caught using excel worksheets you were in trouble), random mid-year in-person interviews by internal auditors; training was rough - not enough access to help when needed and the corporate trainor didn't even know how to use the lending software - sent us back totally unprepared ; they use a program called "core" for underwriting and it is glitchy (for example, when the last condition is cleared the loan will automatically CTC itself. So let's say you cleared all uw conditions, but the title and appraisal were not in file yet. Those come in later and get cleared by the collateral review team. Without any warning, your loan issues it's own clear to close status. This causes you to miss anything new added to the loan before the loan gets audited by QC. Also, once a loan is in CTC status it can never be moved back. So if the loan suddenly isn't ctc anymore (let's say documents expired), it will stay in CTC status, making it hard to manage your pipeline/be aware of the true status of a loan.  Also- the system "recommends" a document to be attached to a condition and people overseas will attach conditions at 2am. (Processors don't really process here, they just resubmit loans when they see that the system recommended a document to a condition). No control at all over what processors do. Underwriter essentially becomes the processor much of the time. Finally, exceptions to credit policy were painstaking to request. Long turn time to get a reply and the system would lock you from making any changes, including canceling the request! This was very annoying.

With the terrible management policies in the last decade the chickens have come home to roost. The key imitative of Scharf and his management team is to get Wells out from under the asset cap and return Wells to the black. This means endless hours of work and cost cutting. This has made it very difficult as an employee, but don't believe there are any 'better' options. I'd not recommend working at Wells Fargo until the asset cap is removed and they are back to a regular dividend.

They are replacing almost all the upper management in the bank and there is a lot of change in the organization. It is hard to keep up with and I have been working longer hours recently. In addition, Wells is hiring non-customer facing finance positions in cheaper cities, so there aren't many finance opportunities in SF. If I want to stay at the bank and have opportunities to move up, I'd probably have to move.

At the time of hire, there was structure to the analyst training program. You would fly out to San Francisco, Minneapolis, or Charlotte (depending on your office location) once a year for training. At the end of your third year, if you had successfully completed the analyst training program, you were able to go through “CMTP”, which was also an in person training program designed to mold analysts into relationship managers or portfolio managers. This has since changed to virtual courses to cut costs (this all occurred pre-COVID), where you’re essentially paid an analyst’s salary to take online classes... looking back on things, there are better training programs (or entry level positions out there.

cons:
Big company problems. From lower to higher management the entire company is CORRUPT. Work abuse, favoritism, intimidation, bias/racism... you name it

They mask it all very well by providing every employee with bogus corporate training and videos that make you believe you're in a safe work environment but you're not. They try to give you the time to take them all but no one ever does because they'd rather use that time to do other activities that help them either keep their job or keep from getting written up. The way they approach development and issues with your work is patronizing. Every meeting is just a series of questions that lead to another question that eventually lead to an explanation of how you're incompetent as an employee. They didn't say it, you say it, so its an HR friendly of telling you you suck, work harder. When you do get something right they pat you on the back and say nice but how come you didn't do this ALSO. The fear of lower level employees drives the lowkey intimidation all of management know they have. Everyone is SCARED to speak up in fear of retaliation. Then the company falls back on the most bogus no retaliation policy that comes way of those useless trainings and videos I mentioned before. So you speak up on the fact retaliation is still happening despite the policy and then the company hides behind an HR department that's suppose to protect you. HR is an absolute joke. Opened several claims to HR even in groups involving half the team members to no avail. Every answer back from them was a professional and corporate friendly way of saying, "we understand and empathize with your problem but we don't agree, deal with it." or "we understand we're going to talk to upper management" then upper management sides with the people you have a problem with because they're buddies. 

Ridiculous work expectations and performance that's globally expected due to the intimidation factor and complete lack of confidence and support. You will feel overworked and absolutely dread or fear coming to work 

Don't make any last minute or even 1-2 week plans in advance you have to ask for vacation 4 weeks in advance and still hope it doesn't interfere with anyone else's schedule

Sunday off but 2nd day off is completely random 

Don't even get me started on the WORST commission structure of all time. especially now that they're apologizing for opening fake accounts. And whatever commission you make gets paid 3 months later, what a joke. 

Lastly depending on your location a certain ethnic group will most likely dominate the work place even up to higher management so you'll experience racism/favoritism to some guaranteed degree if you're not part of that group. But remember they'll mask that too and keep it under wraps with those same bogus policies and a PHENOMENAL HR team. Sarcasm implied*

Getting things done is a bureaucratic nightmare. Everything has to be approved by many different groups or people. If something goes wrong you can't just fix it. Often different departments in the company have no idea what's going on. Also they they try to make it sound like upward mobility is easy and can happen quickly. I've found half of that to be true. The jobs aren't difficult but they do have minimum time in job expectations that make it really difficult to move on in some instances, most aren't policy related either. Just a company culture expectation managers have an attitude of "well I wasn't able to move on for three years so that's what I expect out of people in that position." It can be very frustrating at times.
Lack of training and communication from upper management is a frustrating experience.

Leadership driven changes are not practical in the timeframes laid out. Current systems, data and lack of widespread automation do not allow cross linkage of information. Large investment in data infrastructure and connectivity between systems and hierarchies/taxonomies is desperately needed to support desired changes. Work arounds are being created in Excel to meet leadership direction rather than robust solutions such as connected databases and reporting tools (Tableau).

-Wells Fargo loves being a part of the community they’re in through volunteering and free financial education outside of the branch.
-They still have traditional bank services and features like actual tellers with the option of digital for customers based on preferences.
-Changes are made off of customer and team member feedback vs. company goals. 
-You are able to be the best version of yourself as Wells Fargo allows diversity in backgrounds,thoughts, and ideas which supports our diverse customer base.
-If you consistently work hard, you will be noticed and rewarded no matter how incompetent your manager is!
-Benefits are good, and there are many options available.  New team members start with 12 or 13 days of PTO, 2 personal holidays, and 2 community service days in addition to regular bank holidays.
-The top priority managers teach their team is to focus on the customers need through understanding what’s most important to them and not the bank.

too boring and mundane work to do

-Middle management is a joke and half.  My District Manager stays at home 4/5 days a week and managed by emailing reports. I think I may see them once every other month which is not supportive of my career development. Unfortunately, this a trend from market to market. I’m not sure what happens when someone becomes a DM... someone need to look at that.
-As a Branch Manager, it can be difficult to complete your responsibilities due to staffing issues that never end. It’s hard to be upset, because most of them move to different areas or get promoted. It’s just really hard to get a posting for a new position. 
-Our teller and banker systems are outdated. They have errors and delay customer interactions on a daily basis.
-There is no sales incentive for doing well. More times than not, a branch that has large volumes of customer traffic will always receive higher payout than smaller branches.  The customers literally come to those branches to apply for accounts. They way the incentive is made, branch balance totals are adjusted so frequently that you never understand if your branch is actually growing!  This makes it difficult for a manager to motivate their team to exceed customer expectations each day. I see where they’re coming from.. why work harder when they’re going to pay you incentive for just coming to work LOL.
-The pay structure is silly. Like May companies, they make salary decisions based on how easy or difficult is will be to retain you.  So if I live in an area with less jobs equal to mine at other companies, they have a lower risk of me leaving and pay me less. If I live in an area with a lot of competition for my skills, they pay more. This causes team members to get paid less for the same job someone is doing in another area regardless of their work ethic. Raises? 1% if you perform, 2% if you exceed, 3% if you do some type of sexual favor for your boss if you can find them after they give you keys to the branch. I’m kidding about the 3%. That’s too generous for them. 
-The training has become the worst I’ve ever seen at a company of this size. When I first began in 2012, they taught more in-depth material that allowed you to come into the branch with a basic idea of what you’re doing. Now, my team members come in the branch with two weeks of questions to ask. Unfortunately, the manager has to then choose to do their tasks or support the team member by actually training them. Of course I choose my team members development which leads to extra hours in the Branch for myself after close for everything else. 
-I feel appreciated by upper management, but it’s lip service most of the time. I think they expect my direct manager to do the leg work to make me feel valued and that’s missing completely. After numerous positive customer reviews, the recognition I receive is only based on me teaching other people how to achieve the same business results. Can I at least get a breakfast muffin? Or even an empty bag with an imaginary muffin? Ok, well let’s start with a thank you and go from there  :)
-Geez look at the time - by now you may be thinking I’m a disgruntled employee, but I’m not. I just feel the bank could support areas better than they are and meet the commitments they strive to meet with their team members like they attempt to do with customers.

- Upper management is still resistant to approving full-time Work From Home, even with Covid-19 and a CEO who is remote from NY. Some folks are not being approved for FT WFH, even for jobs that have been done remotely for years now. 
- Conflict-avoidant culture... As reported in the press, serious problems and bad behavior still not directly addressed and allowed to go on for too long.
- Old, institutionalized, dinosaur mentality (mostly 'upstairs') and fear of change. Lots of old white guys in charge, so... yeah.
- Under-performers and folks who just won't do their jobs can easily hide, the org is so large. And because conflict avoidant, these problem folks are never dealt with.
- Salaries are below market for design jobs. Raises don't keep up with inflation.
- The process to get any little thing done is arduous and time intensive. There are so many groups and systems involved, it's redonkulous.

Th he organization has a large number of problems that make it impossible to do your job and enjoy being at Wells. They are as follows:

1. Management: The people in charge have created such a toxic culture that anyone you would want to work under or with leaves within 1-2 years. Many senior RM staff are simply there because they cannot find another job and will make your life very difficult. Throwing underlings under the bus is a regular occurrence and promotion is based on politics and desperation to get someone to stay that has told management they are leaving. 

2: Career Development: There is none unless you are extremely lucky. Trying to move to different groups will often not be allowed and management can deny your transfer for any reason. After this you will be marked as not “loyal” and you essentially have no future. Few, if any of the things you will do will be transferable to real finance jobs so your time in the position will be viewed by other employers as little better then unemployment. Trying to better yourself through school or programs such as the CFA or CAIA is highly discouraged and can lead to outright retaliation in some cases. 

Pay: You will be paid 25-40% less then the same job at other banks and will be paid 30-50% less then what you would make on the principal side in a finance position. Bonuses are reserved for those that feed managements ego so expect to make only 10-25% of your bonus potential no matter how well you preform.

By the time I left:
-They laid off our sister site with little warning, despite our departments doing very well
-They strung contractors along for well over two years before they got frustrated and left; they were dedicated and reliable workers, and new contractors were a mixed bag.
-In my last year, we changed over multiple managers; I believe our immediate manager tried to shield us from a lot of things, but upper management pressed hard, which trickled down to the Processors
-Micro-managing. We were only allowed seven minutes the entire day to use the restroom. As the bathrooms were on the other side of the floor, one visit took 3 1/2 minutes, running. 
-Work environment became toxic, and by the time I left, the turnover rate had been rising.
-Managers no longer were transparent; goals changed frequently without warning, and upper management became obviously disdainful of the Processors when we didn't meet 100% SLA (our team worked with appraisers all over the country, and most of the time if a report didn't come in on time, it meant the appraiser had trouble or just didn't bother doing the report).

As my former coworkers told me, my department no longer exists as it used to.

First, there was the stigma of working at Wells, even though they kept trying to put the negative recent history behind them. The management team in my department treated us like children, even though most of us had extensive experience in the work force. There was no training on the processes when most of us came on board, and processes were constantly changing with no training on the new processes, so we had to figure them out on our own. Then when management didn't like what we did, we would get chastised for it and penalized. There were constant threats and intimidation tactics used, and unrealistic weekly deadlines. There were also threats of senior management taking away the work-from-home flexibility, even though it worked very well for most of us. Most of us were working a lot of unpaid overtime, and there was no flexibility in our work hours, even though we did not work with the general public. The turnover in the department was fairly high, and I learned pretty quickly why that was.

Literally everything else. You'll be fine if your manager likes you, but 1 bad manager can destroy years of work. And you will be moved and you will not have a choice, so it's just luck of the draw if you have a good manager or not. The training is poor, and the only way you'll get support outside of training is if you're lucky enough to have a helpful senior employee. And they will tell you to do things you know are wrong when you get into production so you can try to reach their insane goals.  Probably why they have so many lawsuits all the time. They will tell you there is a bonus structure and then do everything they can to make sure no one can reach their goals to get the bonus, which is why their employees ste worked to death and constantly stressed to their max. Room for advancement is limited and managers can block you from applying to different departments for ANY reason. Really.  ANY reason. Think of what that could mean if someone has some arbitrary issue with you? It's an incredibly toxic work environment and I watched more than one person reach their limit with Wells Fargo in my 7 years with them. It isn't worth it & leaving was the best decision I've ever made for myself and my family.

1) It takes an a tremendous amount of time to get a small amount of work done. Any change requires multiple level of approval, usually by people who have no idea technically what the change does or it's implications.

2) Hypocritical messaging regarding changing behavior for fixing ethics issues and customer abuse while still exhibiting dubious legal behavior.  

3) Some senior developers hide information and resist on-boarding efforts of newer developers to make themselves more valuable. Sink or swim mentality. Assume you have the same knowledge as another developer who has been there for 20 years. Constant use of acronyms and system names in the presence of new employees without explanation so as to make comprehension more difficult.  

4) Absurdly cumbersome processes that have no value. For some reason most seem to think this is acceptable and even engage in enforcing these processes.

5) Can take weeks or even months to get the development tools and access needed to do your job but still expected to get the job done without those tools. 

The list goes on....too long to list here.

Cons greatly outweigh the Pros as you can see from the upcoming rant.

Benefits aren't that great. Still have to pay for the high deductible plan and contribute to an HSA. The deductible is also much higher than what I used to have elsewhere.

Constant reorgs. I accepted an offer, then about a week before my start date the team I joined was put under a different group of which the Manager has no idea why the team is reporting to him! I have not worked on a single thing since I was hired... NOT A SINGLE THING. The reorg has nothing to do with it though, the project pipeline has no future insight. They work on a single project until it is done and THEN decide what the next project is.

SLOW!!!! The team I joined says they've been working on the same project for 3+ years! Everyone that works here seems to be stuck in their old ways, they aren't open to adopt anything new. Skype Audio Meetings are literally just becoming a thing here and no one seems to want to adopt it for some reason, this is a decent example of how far behind they are in terms of using modern technology. They would rather dial in from a VIOP phone AND join a Skype Meeting to view what someone is presenting. Makes no sense to me why no one wants to add audio to the Skype Meeting, it's simple. I'm mind blown by this.

TONS of restrictions. I understand with it being a bank and all, but software that you can install on your system is very limited, no modern technology, all old legacy stuff. You'd think modern tech would have better security vs legacy. Hard to research and learn a topic or simply find a solution to a problem since almost every single site is blocked (except for StackOverflow THANK GOD).

I left a job where I was valued (but underpaid) and worked with tons of other smart engineers for this. Thought I was coming in to be in more of a Lead role and was more motivated than ever. Now I am demotivated, twirling my thumbs everyday trying to keep myself busy....

I could go on and on but I'll stop here. Would not recommend coming here, especially if you're in Tech. Not to mention the bad rep from historical events of which I figured they had moved on from.

review: Great firm to start in the finance industry
pros: Company provided great technology for the day to day tasks.

Great benefits including health insurance ($60ish biweekly for me + children with a $6500 deductible, no copays for regular visits), dental insurance ($15 biweekly), plus other options to include 401(k), life insurance (up to 10x salary), plus you start out with 18 days PTO and after two years you get to 23 days PTO plus 8 paid holidays including 2 personal holidays. Also PAID leaves of absences that don't come out of your PTO balance - critical caregivers leave (up to 5 days), primary caregiver parental leave (16 weeks), secondary caregiver parental leave (4 weeks), short term disability (6 weeks), long term disability, etc etc. The benefits are why I haven't switched to a job closer to home.

Wells Fargo at this call center only hires new CSRs through employment agencies, so if you accept this position be prepared to make $13.50 to $14.00 an hour for the same work that your "official" Wells Fargo employed team members are making $19 to $25 an hour to do. If anything, you will work harder, because all the calls not requiring "special handling" will get routed to you. You will take back to back calls all day every day, while your team members chat about their lives and weekend plans. And I know, "I get paid either way", but sure not paid enough.
We are promised a good chance of being "hired on" after a certain amount of time and proving ourselves as valuable employees, and finally attaining the job security, pay increase, PTO, vacation days, sick time, and stock options, but believe me, it's just a carrot on a stick held in front of you to make you give maximum effort for minimum compensation.
Why are they paying agencies big money to bring us in, full background checks, FBI fingerprinting, eight weeks of paid training, and then hiring only one agency person on in the past 6 months? Because there is a possibility this site may shut down in the next year or two, and all agency employees aren't going to need that severance package, right?
And good attendance, people skills, and work ethic won't get you hired as an official employee, you have to market Wells Fargo products. "It's not selling stuff, it's 'having a conversation' ". OK. After the Wells Fargo scandals over marketing products, (Google it if you don't know, I had to) you would not think you'd have to sell stuff to people who call in with concerns about keeping their homes to get hired here, but you do. If someone calls in looking to refinance, sure, but if someone calls in and immediately launches in to "why weren't my taxes paid out of my escrow?!?!", and there's a note on their account to try to sell them another mortgage, it is held against you if you don't do it! The survey system is ridiculous, their opinion of your service is lumped right in with how the customer perceives Well Fargo. The American people don't trust or respect Wells Fargo, and you are not paid enough to try to make the overpaid bosses look good. As an agency employee, you will be treated differently, all my fellow agency employees will back me up on this. Left out of team potlucks, generally left to our own devices to figure stuff out, reminded snidely to "call Robert Half, or Dysis, or Sparks" or whoever your employment agency is, if a customer recommends in a review that you get a raise or a compliment. If you think your agency pay is in anyway compensation for what you'll be doing, think again. If you think you're so awesome you'll be hired on within a year, think again.

Several days a week you will be the only bilingual associate and will be taking two to three times the workload and you assume all risk both in losses with your register and approvals done at the teller line and not to mention the risk you assume opening consumer accounts. They came up with the title of business advocate to avoid paying you more but having the same responsability of a PB2. A PB2 does the same as a business advocate only that position actually pays you bonuses  and a raise in your salary. We get alot of days off but have no money to do anything unless you live rent free with your parents, which in many cases its the norm.

Management/HR are very deceiving when it comes to the licensing program. They tell you they give you a 60 day window (2 months) to study and take the test. They also say be sure not to study on your own time or have any overtime because they will not pay you outside Monday-Friday within operating hours. What they dont tell you is, they dont care for you to pass, they really cut short your time by counting the days by calendar days not by business days. If you don't feel ready or prepared to take the test they will not allow you to extend the time frame, and the PassPerfect program you utilize is mandatory. They will not expense for you to use Kaplan or any other service. Studying for a Series 6,63,65 takes a lot of time to study for and FINRA allows a 90 day window just to prepare and study for one exam.
