-management plays huge role in your Work/life balance

pros: Good benefits, excellent training, and fair pay.

Managers are trained to help you succeed and develop a career path and help set you up to exceed. There are many training platforms that you can take if you wish. You can job shadow in a different dept. to see if its what you really want to apply for. There are no longer any sales goals. They are rated by reviews and putting the customer first. It is a very customer sentric company now. In the retirement center they were fantastic, understanding of any learning curve new associates have. You are helped by teammates as well as management. The amount of time my manager spent with me was shocking compared to other companies. You actually looked forward to them stopping by instead of dreading it. You are not yelled at for a mistake at all. I Love this company. I only left because my boyfriends father got leukemia in Arizona. I can reapply and come back, but I am moving.

Their benefits are spectacular. in addition to your PTO they also provide you with 2 additional days to use on personal holidays for those of us that celebrate other holidays, you also get 2 more days to use for volunteering (can even be to supervise a school trip with your kid!). You also can use your PTO whenever you want, it does not have to accrue (Unless you quit and have used more than you have technically earned, then you have to pay back what the difference is, obviously.) I can't say enough good about Wells. I was Anti-Wells and pissed at them for a long while. They have really turned around!

Very hard to move laterally. Since Wells Fargo relies heavily on Contract to hire roles for most of it's roles it makes it hard to move laterally in the company. 
Here is my breakdown on why the contract to hire model is a very very poor tool for Wells Fargo. 

1) Most Staffing agencies will ignore your resume or not work with you because that is considered poaching

2) Those same staffing companies will in turn hire outside talent that are generally not familiar with Wells Fargo software, policies, or have experience.

3) Existing employees are never given the opportunity to move laterally since the roles they want are being filled by staffing companies so they in turn get frustrated and quit.

The customers are wild because Wells Fargo enables them to be. The management makes decisions that if they were actually doing your job, they wouldn't make. They are behind technologically. Their app does not have a lot of things. They do not pay enough for what they make you do. I was a regular phone banker and they made us all go through online banking training which is another set of skills. For two weeks you were trained then thrown on the phone with those new set of skills with the SAME SALARY. That was crazy to me. I had to spend longer times on the phone for I was doing more trying to troubleshoot for customers and was making the same amount of money before learning the skills. That's terrible. They don't listen or care about their employees. They will bribe you with food if their surveys are low or you seem unsatisfied. I also do believe Wells Fargo is related with money laundering for sure and they foster an environment for their customers that enable them to stay poor. Their app does not have an ending balance after each transaction just at the end of the day after the transactions post so customers are always irate for the overdraft fees they get a bunch of them.  Worst company I ever worked for never felt so uninmportant.

Benefits and Compensation was good
I love my job as a teller, most of my teammates have so much knowledge and they are more than willing to help me when i need it.

1) You get 18 days of PTOs and two personal Holidays for the first two years. Afterwards, you get 23 days of PTOs and two personal Holidays. You get more PTOs once you work for the company for more than 7-8 years. You get 4 months paid for maternal leave.
2) There's a backup daycare service eligible for team members. I have a little baby and I use this benefit whenever my babysitter isn't available. You can use 20 days of backup daycare services per year, and I get to pay just $20 per day for one child (company pays for the rest). The daycare I get to send costs $2100 per month if you send him/her full-time. 
3) Great management - My district manager, branch manager, assistant manager, and service managers all care about my growth & development and my well-being at the same time. I feel truly blessed to work with great team members. 
4) There's no sales goal , which means less pressure. All we have to do is helping customers based on what their needs are, and never force them for any product that they don't want.

No management support. Refinance loans take 3-4 months to close. Underwriters are so worried about getting fired for making a bad loan that they try to kill good loans rather than to find ways to make them work. Interest rates are .25% higher than any other company. Loan processors are buried so they don't like talking to customers.

- The marketing organization has shifted over the past 3 years - it is now extremely process oriented. As a result, all programs, projects and campaigns take 3 times longer than they used to. The "process" is extremely inflexible and inefficient.
- Continuous layoffs in marketing has lead to poor work/life balance as the work of those leaving is given to others who already have more work than they can handle. And often the work that is transitioning to the employees that remain is higher level work, however, there are no changes to compensation or job levels.
- Constant changes in marketing processes and systems have created a lot of confusion within the marketing organization - ask 5 different people a simple question about one of the process steps and you'll get 5 different answers. 
- Due to the scandals over the last few years, risk, compliance and legal reviews are extremely challenging making it all that more difficult to get the work done. This coupled with all the process makes it extremely challenging to find joy in your work at WF, and makes you feel as though you are set up to fail.

cons:
-Pay for internal employees. They do not value loyalty. A person working in the role for 10+ years will never see any more pay then their annual "cost of living" pay which is below the market, they give you 2% yearly. If you get another internal job offer they can't raise your pay more than a certain % (normally no more than 10%), whereas if you were an external candidate, you can come in with the mid pay and surpass the loyal employee who has been doing it for more than a new person joining. 
-They advertise the mid pay on all their openings yet do not pay anywhere close to that amount. Because everything is considered a "lateral" move to upper management when it's not. Like coming from a regular staff to becoming a manager of a dept is considered lateral so they don't have to pay you the mid or anything more. They need to reasses what lateral means. 
-Poor senior management communication
-Too many levels of management to get an approval
-Too compartmentalize, there's a person for every single thing, so you get a lot of, "we don't do that" and then transfer to another department and then the same thing happen. Home Office does not take any accountability.
-Lazy and incompetent home office staff located in St. Louis.
-Uses offshore India and Phillipines, language barrier and makes a lot of mistakes, and don't understand some things. 
-Complaints or suggestion system for "excellence first" goes no where.
Management is a mess, and company currently has no real vision.

Wells Fargo's is an extremely challenging environment and culture. Egregious lacks of processes and controls create an environment fraught with uncertainty and a management and workforce that is generally hesitant to excel or challenge the status quo unless instructed to do so. Too many senior leaders in the company that have been in the same group or role for far too long, resulting in an elusive and defensive culture that has been extremely challenging to disrupt. I understand some of this has been improving over the last year as much of the dead weight in middle and upper management is being challenged or pushed out all together.

The brand reputation is still "not good enough" following the scandals and employees aren't happy with their annual raises while EVP's continue to enjoy the lifestyle of $7M+ houses in California and tout "strategic alignment". Opportunities for advancement are limited and it takes a LONG time to go through the HR cycle. Many issues are based on the fact that many folks come from the small rural banks that WF bought a few decades ago. Those folks now have tenure and decision-making power, but may not have the global experience or mindset for innovation.  Initiatives take years (decades?) to complete. Some processes are very antiquated because the bank is so big. Basically you may need to drink the WF Kool-Aid to grow professionally, and that may come at a cost to your own timeline.

-Ridiculous metrics, especially Average Handle Time. They care more about you having quick calls than actually solving the customers' problems. They tell you in training don't worry about AHT because the customer experience is more important. But once you get out of training, if your AHT is high, which is normal, you will constantly get nagged over it and micromanaged. AHT is probably the most important metric to them because they say the company spends millions of dollars in operation costs every second you're on the phone. But if you don't completely solve the customer's probably they'll have to call back and take up more time. I've had managers give us tips for how to get customers off the phone before they bring up another thing they need help with so that you can meet the AHT metric. Bad business practice.
-They sell you on the bonus you could get based on customer experience surveys. But even if you do really well in that, you won't get it even if your AHT is a couple seconds too high or if you had a QA dock and you're even a point off the requirement. But the rest of your team will still get a bonus based on the team's customer survey scores including your scores in the average.
-Even if you get a high score in your schedule adherence, your ability to solve the customer's problem on the first call, high customer scores, high quality assurance scores, etc, if your AHT isn't perfect even if you've brought it down, you won't get any reward and very little recognition.
-You get some good customers but you'll get a lot who scream at you, cuss at you, personally insult you and your intelligence, etc. and the company does little to prevent these types of customers from calling in and treating team members that way.
-There's very little flexibility to actually help customers and I agree some policies aren't fair to them. Those are tough calls to take and you get them a lot.
-No time to breath with maximum nine seconds between calls. Back to back for 8-10 hours. If you get up to use the bathroom outside of breaks it affects your schedule adherence. Every second of your time is micromanaged and you start to feel like a child and it's hard to regroup after a call.
-Too many coachings. At least once a week, but can be multiple times a week. They  will also plug in and listen to your calls while you take them to coach you, which is very stressful and inefficient. The occasional coaching and performance review is good. But too often starts to feel overwhelming and like a punishment. I don't know any adults at their job who are coached that often.
-Sometimes you will get a cool manager. Sometimes you will get one who micromanages worse than most and tracks you down to remind you to go to a meeting instead of trusting you to be an adult and check your own schedule. They will make you fill out unnecessary forms about your calls as you go through them. The will move you around on teams so if you get a good manager, don't get too comfortable.
-If you go to a manager needing help for something with benefits, leaves, your schedule, etc, they will either give you incorrect info because they don't know much. Or they won't help you at all and claim there's nothing they can do for you when they can.
-We once had a meeting with our manager's boss to give anonymous feedback. Beforehand said manager complained about anonymous feedback he was given previously. After the meeting, he talked to each employee individually and reworded the comments as questions to figure out who said what.
-If you have advice for how something can be done better or how they can help you to do your job better, they won't listen to it because they "have to" do things the way they are
-This job will ruin your mental health and make you anxious and drained all the time. You learn that rude customers aren't making it personal, but hours of that a day still drains you and makes it hard to focus. This makes the pay not even worth it between that and the micromanaging.

Right after the financial crisis of 2008, Wells Fargo was considered "the best" of the big banks, with its reputation and customer service seen as better than its key competitors. In 2016 unfortunately, there were negative sales practices that came to light; this had a significant negative impact on the bank's reputation, its team members, and its business. Because of this, the bank has really tried to do an extensive audit of its practices, incorporate all necessary controls, and make customers whole. These actions continue until today, so most of the bank's initiatives are still geared toward's fixing what is wrong. The company has struggled with costs, process improvement, driving consumer growth, and corresponding lack of morale among its employees. I think the company's core is good, and is sincerely trying to improve. It has, and will take more time for it to regain a positive reputation among customers.

The hiring process is a joke, archaic and bureaucratic. The pay alone deters top talent, and you’re flat out lied to about what you’ll realistically make. The scoring metrics that affect your pay are set up to make you fail. You have to depend on incompetent and apathetic fulfillment partners to make a loan go through. But my role’s pay is adversely affected by their poor performance, but my performance has no negative impacts on their compensation. This leads to a combative and toxic work environment. 

Work life balance is a joke, and this is not a good fit for working parents. You’re pressured into working overtime every week. You’re bound to an inbound call schedule that will prohibit you from taking breaks that are required by law, and management constantly expects more production for no benefit to the worker. This schedule is also subject to change daily so you can never effectively plan your day or week. 

Expect to make about $50k a year, and this business is extremely detailed and complex to learn, so there’s a heavy ramp up period. 

The complex is rodent-infested and often smells like decay. Don’t eat at the cafeterias.

The culture and work environment is pretty toxic. The sales people are so underpaid that they are unwilling to play as a team and help each other, management does nothing but track reports. There’s no real coaching or career planning opportunities. The whole company agenda is to bring in as much business as possible without having to pay out for it. There is no reason why an employee who brings in $25+ million worth of business annually for a company should have to scrape by to pay their bills.

Many of my criticisms of Wells Fargo stem from what appear to be huge gaps in competency and an overall lack of planning across the financial crimes risk management group.  It should be noted that these points apply to Anti-Money Laundering only.

Management has been moving forward with a plan, despite widespread criticism at the investigator level, to move all teams to a 5 days in office/5 days working from home plan.  This plan would be so rigid as to force you to use your own PTO if you were unable to be in the office or work from home on your assigned week.  Our team has repeatedly been misled, beginning with our initial interviews, on the leniency of the company's work from home policy.  As our team has bounced between leaders, each has arbitrarily raised the required minimum days remaining on cases in our queue to prevent us from working remotely.  Leadership has also repeatedly dangled the prospect of across the board promotions to all Financial Crimes Consultant 2 team members to FC 3, however, as this has been in talks for over a year, and we are in yet another hiring freeze, this appears to be just another tall tale.  

There appears to be little to no room for advancement in Philadelphia, as financial crimes compliance is frequently subject to hiring freezes, and they appear to be pushing to remove us physically from the building based on the above working from home plan.

This theme of arbitrary leadership decisions is a problem across all aspects of our work, and is exacerbated by the clear lack of industry knowledge and proper priorities for compliance investigations groups at all levels of management on the East Coast, but particularly at the manager and director level.  Wells Fargo's program requires each and every case to be scrutinized by your direct manager, who often apply their own questionable nitpicks to what should be a streamlined, consistent production-based environment.  Some managers have next to no financial crimes experience, knowledge of company systems, or leadership skills.  If you are used to any autonomy in your investigative work, you will hate it here.  This is the only investigative group I've been a part of where the managers have no cases of their own to complete, and are essentially QR (even though there is an actual QR with much more lenient standards as they service all teams). 

These huge inconsistencies between teams are the result of an overall lack of written policies and procedures I had never encountered in a compliance program before coming to Wells Fargo.  What little written guidance there is is often supplemented by verbal updates from leadership with questionable understanding of the issues at hand, and often are never even added in writing to the compliance manuals.  Teams with the same pay grade, investigative mandates, and case loads are hugely inconsistent across the company to a level I had not though imaginable.  This can mean the difference between one team only having to review a single account for a month time span, with another team for the same referral having to review 20 accounts over a year.  There appears to be an established culture of managers and directors with no real productive casework to do, who are encouraged to add their own anal guidelines for their respective teams down the chain.  Every single policy change I have seen, at the director or manager level, has consisted of them adding more work for us to do, or curtailing our privileges.  It is especially insulting having compliance experience in mature programs and knowing that these changes are never actually the result of guidance stemming from the federal government or an audit, but middle managers seeking to appear more strict and thorough than the next, as they view our teams as another stepping stone to move up.

Philadelphia morale remains low as our teams are again and again subject to rules which we see our colleagues in other regions, lucky enough to be under qualified leadership, not have to deal with.  Management holds us to the quantitative standards of a high volume production environment, and appears unable to create efficient processes to succeed with that level of case work.  Our case load has increased unbelievably in our time, from what was an expected 3 cases completed per day, to what is now 5.  It is impossible to conduct in depth reviews given that volume yet managers constantly push for more to be completed.  We feel that we are always bearing the burden of management's lack of planning which caused this situation, as we are constantly understaffed, and see arbitrary priority level escalations, new monitoring referral sources, and ill-conceived policies be implemented every day.

After 18 years of working here, I am seeing all back office jobs move to countries where the labor is less expensive. The managers responsible for all that you read about are still here, just in different management roles. You really think they're not going to find a way to cheat?  I would not be surprised if we all hear something else within the next 12 months.

Wells Fargo has unethical sales practices. They teach you to Target those who are vulnerable to making poor financial choices so that they can push them into new loans and credit cards. The business model is focused on sales, not service. You have to offer products to every customer who comes in. Customers were often frustrated with the pestering. The good, honest, kind employees were pushed out while the aggressive, unethical employees were promoted.
Base salary only given for first few months.
